questions.text: A 57-year-old man presents to the gastroenterology clinic for a routine colonoscopy. The patient is found to have a tumor located in the sigmoid colon, which is infiltrating into the descending large intestine. Biopsies of the tumor are taken on colonoscopy and are found to be aggressive colonic adenocarcinoma. Molecular studies are pending. PET scan shows metastatic disease reaching lymph nodes and the portal system. Which of the following is the strongest prognostic factor and target for treating this patient’s colorectal cancer?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with a colonic adenocarcinoma with metastasis to the liver and peripheral lymph nodes. While several mutations are associated with the development of metastatic colorectal cancer, only BRAF is highly prognostic and targetable. 

BRAF is a key intermediary in the choices listed MAPK signaling cascade, leading to the activation of ERK (see image). Some colorectal cancers can develop a V600E mutation of BRAF, driving high ERK signaling output independently. Similar mutations in BRAF are common in melanomas and some thyroid cancers and are associated with more aggressive phenotypes.  Therefore, inhibition of BRAF signaling is a key aspect of treatment in these cancers, as it significantly stifles cell proliferation in aberrant cells. BRAF inhibition is seldom used alone and is often combined with inhibition of complement pathways of tumorigenesis, including EGFR, MEK, PI3K, and Wnt pathways. BRAF inhibitors include encorafenib, dabrafenib, and vemurafenib. Side effects of these medications include the development of skin abnormalities such as kerato-acanthomas, diarrhea, fatigue, and arthralgias.    

Option Analysis

❌ VEGF mutations :
Incorrect: VEGF mutations are common in many solid cancers. They have little clinical significance in diagnosing and treating metastatic colon cancer.  
✅ BRAF V600E mutations :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Age at initial diagnosis:
Incorrect: While age is an important aspect of colon cancer screening, age is not the strongest prognostic factor for patients who have metastatic colon cancer, nor is it targetable for therapy 
❌ Family history of disease :
Incorrect: While family history is an important factor in colon cancer screening, it is not the strongest prognostic factor for patients who have metastatic colon cancer, nor is it targetable for therapy. 
❌ Microsatellite instability :
Incorrect: Microsatellite instability (MSI) is associated with colon cancer and BRAF mutations; however, prognostically, having a BRAF mutation is more prognostically significant than MSI.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman comes to her physician after being diagnosed with non-Hodgkin lymphoma. She is being treated with rituximab. Based on its naming convention, what kind of monoclonal antibody is rituximab?
questions.solution:
Monoclonal antibodies are a collection of relatively new classes of therapeutic biologic agents. As the name suggests, monoclonal antibodies are antibodies created from a single parent cell exogenously. They bind to specific protein targets on the extracellular cell membrane of tumors or virus-ridden cells. The parent cell where the antibody was created may vary, with some being created in different mammalian cells such as hamsters, primates, mice, etc. Furthermore, antibodies can be chimeric, fuzing variable regions from one species like a mouse, with another such as humans. While the suffix of all monoclonal antibodies ends with “-mab”, substems precede the suffix that describes the origin of the drug (see table below). In the case of rituximab, the “xi” substem shows that this agent is a chimeric monoclonal antibody.  

Option Analysis

❌ Primate :
Incorrect: Primate monoclonal antibodies have the substem “-i-.” 
❌ Mouse :
Incorrect: Mouse monoclonal antibodies have the substem “-o-.”  
❌ Hamster :
Incorrect: Hamster monoclonal antibodies have the substem “-e-.” 
❌ Humanized :
Incorrect: Humanized monoclonal antibodies have the substem “-zu.” 
✅ Chimeric  :
Correct: see main explanation.

questions.text: A 72-year-old man presents to the office because of pain and bulging in his groin. The patient reports that standing exacerbates the pain. The patient is otherwise healthy and has never had surgery. He does not take any medications. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination shows a bulge in the groin that is erythematous and painful to palpation. Scrotal examination is within normal limits. After further evaluation, the patient is diagnosed with a femoral hernia and is scheduled for an endoscopic repair under spinal anesthesia. Which of the following structures is at risk of injury in this patient during the repair?
questions.solution:
This patient with pain and bulging in the groin is found to have a femoral hernia. During femoral hernia repair, sometimes an artery called the aberrant, or accessory, obturator artery can be injured. Typically, the obturator artery branches from the internal iliac artery. In up to 20% of people, however, there can be an additional branch coming from either the inferior epigastric artery or external iliac artery that either replaces the obturator artery or joins it; this phenomenon is called an aberrant or accessory obturator artery. In these patients, the artery runs in close proximity to the femoral ring and courses along the superior pubic rami; so, during hernia repair, it can be injured or stapled.  

When injury occurs, the artery retracts, making it exceedingly difficult to locate and ligate, resulting in uncontrolled bleeding. This artery has been referred to as corona mortis, which means “crown of death,” as injury to it can be fatal.  

 

Option Analysis

❌ Ilioinguinal nerve:
Incorrect: The ilioinguinal, iliohypogastric, and genitofemoral nerves are at risk of injury during inguinal hernia repair, which can lead to chronic residual neuralgia and postoperative constrictive scar tissue in the surgical area. However, this patient is undergoing repair for a femoral hernia, which poses risk to a different key structure.
❌ Iliohypogastric nerve:
Incorrect: The ilioinguinal, iliohypogastric, and genitofemoral nerves are at risk of injury during inguinal hernia repair, which can lead to chronic residual neuralgia and postoperative constrictive scar tissue in the surgical area. However, this patient is undergoing repair for a femoral hernia, which poses risk to a different key structure.
❌ Genitofemoral nerve:
Incorrect: The ilioinguinal, iliohypogastric, and genitofemoral nerves are at risk of injury during inguinal hernia repair, which can lead to chronic residual neuralgia and postoperative constrictive scar tissue in the surgical area. However, this patient is undergoing repair for a femoral hernia, which poses risk to a different key structure.
✅ Aberrant obturator artery:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Pudendal nerve:
Incorrect: The pudendal nerve is at risk of injury during sacrospinous ligament fixation or pelvic reconstructive procedures, during which sutures are placed in the arcus tendineus fasciae pelvis. However, this patient is undergoing repair for a femoral hernia, which poses risk to a different key structure.

questions.text:
A 64-year-old man comes to the office for the evaluation of a mass on the right side of his groin. The patient first noted the mass after helping his daughter move to a new home. He reports sharp discomfort in the right groin worsens with walking and heavy lifting. Resting supine decreases the severity of the pain. Past medical history is significant for type 2 diabetes mellitus. Current medications include atorvastatin and metformin. BMI is 37 kg/m2. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination shows a bulge in the right groin above the inguinal ligament which increases in size when the patient coughs. There is no overlying erythema or warmth. The patient is referred to a surgeon and scheduled for a laparoscopic repair.



Which of the following landmarks will help the surgeon to differentiate a direct versus an indirect inguinal hernia?
questions.solution:
This patient with an examination finding of a bulge in the right groin above the inguinal ligament has most likely developed an inguinal hernia. Inguinal hernias are located above the inguinal ligament. They are classified into direct and indirect hernias. The inferior epigastric vessels are easily visible during laparoscopic hernia repair and are an important landmark to differentiate between the two types of inguinal hernias.

Direct inguinal hernias result from weakness of the transversalis fascia, which makes up the floor of the Hesselbach triangle. Other boundaries include the inferior epigastric vessels laterally, the inguinal ligament inferiorly, and the rectus abdominis muscle medially.

Indirect inguinal hernias are the most common type of groin hernia and result from a patent processus vaginalis. They are bounded medially by the inferior epigastric artery. The herniated abdominal contents enter through the deep inguinal ring into the inguinal canal and exit through the superficial inguinal ring. The deep inguinal ring is an oval opening in the transversalis fascia located at the midpoint of the inguinal ligament (between the anterior superior iliac spine and the pubic tubercle).

Option Analysis

❌ A:
Incorrect: Structure A represents the inguinal ligament, which stretches from the anterior superior iliac spine to the pubic tubercle. It is an important landmark to differentiate between inguinal and femoral hernias but cannot differentiate between direct and indirect inguinal hernias.
❌ B:
Incorrect: Structure B represents the transversalis fascia, which forms the posterior wall of inguinal canal, and its weakness can result in the development of direct inguinal hernia. However, the transversalis fascia is not used for inguinal hernia differentiation.
✅ C:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ D:
Incorrect: Structure D represents the deep inguinal ring, which is the entrance site of the inguinal canal. It is found above the midpoint of the inguinal ligament, lateral to the epigastric vessels.
❌ E:
Incorrect: Structure E represents the spermatic cord. Indirect inguinal hernias follow the path of the spermatic cord via the deep inguinal ring. However, the spermatic cord is not used for inguinal hernia differentiation..

questions.text: A 65-year-old woman comes to the emergency department because of nausea, vomiting, and abdominal distention for the past 12 hours. She has had vague abdominal pain for the past few months but did not seek medical care. Past medical history is significant for type 2 diabetes mellitus, managed with metformin. BMI is 35 kg/m2. Temperature is 38.4°C (101°F), pulse is 89/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 135/85 mmHg. Physical examination shows moderate abdominal distension. There is a 3 cm erythematous and tender palpable mass in the right groin below the inguinal ligament and lateral to the pubic tubercle. The mass is tympanitic to percussion and cannot be reduced. CT scan of the abdomen shows evidence of small bowel obstruction. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient’s condition?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with an irreducible groin bulge lateral to the pubic tubercle and below the inguinal ligament; she most likely has an incarcerated femoral hernia. Since it is erythematous and is associated with abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, and high-grade fever, it has most likely strangulated.

Femoral hernias are the result of herniation of abdominal contents through the femoral canal below the inguinal ligament, medial to the femoral vein, and lateral to the pubic tubercle. Femoral hernias are more common in females and often occur on the right side. Advanced age is the most important risk factor, as the femoral ring can widen. Because the femoral canal is small, femoral hernias often become incarcerated (irreducible), which can lead to bowel obstruction (resulting in pain, nausea, and abdominal distension). Over time, strangulation (ischemia and necrosis) can occur due to worsening edema secondary to impaired blood flow.

In contrast, inguinal hernias are associated with a comparatively lower risk of incarceration and strangulation, as the bowel contents protrude via a wider orifice.

Femoral hernias require surgical repair to decrease the morbidity and mortality associated with potentially life-threatening complications. In some patients, an accessory (or aberrant) obturator artery (a branch of inferior epigastric artery) passes medial to the femoral ring along the margin of the lacunar ligament. The surgeon must be careful to avoid its injury while cutting the lacunar ligament to enlarge the femoral ring to reduce the hernia.



Option Analysis

❌ Patent processus vaginalis:
Incorrect: A patent processus vaginalis can result in indirect inguinal hernia, which would present above the inguinal ligament.
✅ Widening of the femoral ring:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Weakness of transversalis fascia:
Incorrect: Weakness of transversalis fascia can result in a direct inguinal hernia, which protrudes medially to the inferior epigastric vessels within the Hesselbach triangle and appear in the groin. Inguinal hernias are found above the inguinal ligament.
❌ Defect in the Spigelian aponeurosis:
Incorrect: A defect in the Spigelian aponeurosis can result in a Spigelian hernia, which would be located in the "Spigelian hernia belt," a transverse, 6-centimeter-wide zone around the level of the arcuate line (the caudal-most extent of the posterior rectus sheath). This patient instead has a femoral hernia, which results from laxity of the femoral ring.
❌ Dilatation of long saphenous vein:
Incorrect: Saphenous varix is the dilatation of a long saphenous vein at its junction with the femoral vein in the groin. It appears as a bulge with bluish tinge below the inguinal ligament. It disappears on lying down and exhibits a thrill on auscultation. It is usually associated with varicose veins. This patient’s presentation is more consistent with a femoral hernia.

questions.text: A 74-year-old man comes to the office because of a small bulge on the right side of his groin. The patient first noted the lesion after helping his daughter move to a new home. He reports sharp discomfort in the right groin worsens with walking and heavy lifting. Resting supine decreases the severity of the pain. Past medical history is significant for hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus. Current medications include lisinopril, atorvastatin, and metformin. BMI is 35.5 kg/m2. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination shows a bulge in the right groin above the inguinal ligament, which increases in size when the patient coughs. There is no overlying erythema or warmth. An ultrasound reveals that the bulge originates medial to the inferior epigastric vessels. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient’s presentation?

choices.text: Dilatation of the long saphenous vein
Failure of closure of the processus vaginalis

questions.solution:
This patient’s groin mass protruding medial to the inferior epigastric vessels is characteristic of a direct inguinal hernia in the Hesselbach triangle.

Inguinal hernias make up to 96% of groin hernias. They can be classified into direct or indirect hernias. They develop more frequently on the right in both sexes, which is thought to be due to a later descent of the right testicle in males and due to the asymmetry of the pelvis in females.

Direct inguinal hernias result from weakness of the transversalis fascia that makes up the floor of the Hesselbach triangle. Other boundaries include inferior epigastric vessels laterally, the inguinal ligament inferiorly, and the rectus abdominis muscle medially. Contents bulge through the external or superficial inguinal ring only and are covered by the external spermatic fascia. Inguinal hernias are most commonly seen in older males.



Indirect hernias are the most common type of groin hernia and result from a patent processus vaginalis. They are located lateral to the inferior epigastric artery and protrude through the internal inguinal ring, which is the site where the spermatic cord in males and the round ligament in females exits the abdomen.



Option Analysis

❌ Dilatation of the long saphenous vein:
Incorrect: Saphenous varix is the dilatation of the long saphenous vein at its junction with the femoral vein in the groin. It appears as a bulge with a bluish tinge below the inguinal ligament. It disappears on lying down and exhibits a thrill on auscultation. It is usually associated with varicose veins. This patient’s presentation is more consistent with a direct inguinal hernia.
❌ Testicular neoplasm:
Incorrect: Testicular neoplasm is a rare condition that presents a firm testicular mass that does not change with positioning or Valsalva maneuver. This patient’s presentation is more consistent with a direct inguinal hernia.
✅ Weakness of the transversalis fascia:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Failure of closure of the processus vaginalis:
Incorrect: Failure of closure of the processus vaginalis can result in indirect inguinal hernias, which present lateral to the inferior epigastric vessels (unlike this patient).
❌ Widening of the femoral ring:
Incorrect: Widening of the femoral ring can result in a femoral hernia, which protrudes in the upper thigh medial to the femoral vein (not epigastric vessels).

questions.text: A 65-year-old woman comes to the emergency department because of groin pain, nausea, and abdominal distention for the past 12 hours. She has not experienced similar symptoms before. Past medical history is significant for type 2 diabetes mellitus, managed with metformin. BMI is 33 kg/m2. Temperature is 38.4°C (101°F), pulse is 89/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 135/85 mmHg. Physical examination shows mild abdominal distension. There is a 5cm palpable mass in the left groin that cannot be reduced and has overlying erythema. It is bounded medially by the pubic tubercle and laterally by a pulsating artery. Which of the following structures is most likely immediately superior to the bulge?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with groin discomfort and a bulge lateral to the pubic tubercle and medial to a pulsating artery (femoral artery) with associated nausea and abdominal distension; she most likely has a strangulated femoral hernia, which is a herniation of the bowel through the femoral canal below the inguinal ligament, medial to the femoral vessels, and lateral to the pubic tubercle and pectineal ligament.

Femoral hernias occur more often in females, though advanced age is the most important risk factor as the femoral ring can widen with age. Because the femoral canal is small, femoral hernias often become incarcerated (irreducible), and patients can present with signs of a bowel obstruction (pain, nausea, abdominal distension) if a bowel segment is herniated in the sac. Over time, strangulation (ischemia and necrosis) can occur due to worsening edema secondary to impaired blood flow.

In contrast to femoral hernias, direct and indirect inguinal hernias are located above the inguinal ligament. These are more common in males. Chronic increase in intra-abdominal pressure and advanced age are important risk factors. The incidence of incarceration and strangulation is low as compared to femoral hernia.



Option Analysis

❌ Pectineal ligament:
Incorrect: The pectineal ligament is an extension of the lacunar ligament and runs along the pectineal line of the pubic bone. It forms the posterior border of the femoral canal.
✅ Inguinal ligament:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Rectus muscle sheath:
Incorrect: The rectus muscle sheath is an aponeurosis that encloses the rectus abdominis muscle. It forms the medial border of the Hesselbach triangle and is medial to direct inguinal hernias. It is not related to the femoral ring or femoral hernias.
❌ Round ligament:
Incorrect: The round ligament is homologous to the spermatic cord in males. It passes through the deep inguinal ring to enter the inguinal canal. The round ligament is not associated with the anatomy of a femoral hernia.
❌ Inferior epigastric vessels:
Incorrect: The inferior epigastric vessels are an important landmark for the differentiation of direct and indirect inguinal hernias. Direct hernias protrude medial to inferior epigastric vessels, whereas indirect inguinal hernias run lateral to them before entering the inguinal canal. However, this patient has a femoral hernia.

questions.text:
A 41-year-old man presents to the emergency department to be evaluated for recent-onset of sharp abdominal pain. The patient’s symptoms began during weight lifting. The patent was performing a bench press and immediately afterward felt sharp abdominal pain in the right lower quadrant. The pain has been constant and increasing in severity. Vital signs are within normal limits. Past surgical history is notable for a Roux-en-Y gastric bypass performed one year ago. There is abdominal guarding on physical examination. Palpation of the abdomen causes severe pain. A stat CT is done, revealing the finding shown below. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient’s symptoms?    


Image reproduced from Indian Journal of Radiology and Imaging
questions.solution:
The greater omentum is an important sheet-like curtain of vascularized fatty tissue which hangs down from the greater curvature of the stomach, draping over the intestines. The purpose of the greater omentum is threefold: 1) Fatty thermal insulation and a physical promotility agent for the intestines, 2) physical barrier to protect against infections and wounds, and 3) centralized hub for immune activity.    

Pathologies involving the omentum are rare. The greater omentum can undergo torsion, whereby the omentum pivots on its long axis and cuts off its blood supply. The greater omentum can whorl around a nidus of adhesion or tumor, as is seen in the CT above. Since the omentum is vascularized, this whorling is an acute surgical emergency as it can cause acute ischemia and subsequent necrosis of the omentum. Torsion of the greater omentum can present as an acute abdomen. The twisted segment is often localized to the right-side segment and presentation with acute right lower quadrant abdominal pain can mimic acute appendicitis. However nausea and vomiting are typically absent.    

Greater omental torsion can be primary when there is no underlying abnormality or secondary when an underlying lesion is the cause of torsion such as with post-surgical adhesions as seen in this case. It has been postulated that torsion of the greater omentum is caused by the greater length and mobility of the right side of the omentum due to the differing embyologic origins of the omentum.  

Option Analysis

❌ Developmental anomaly:
Incorrect: These findings are characteristic of omental torsion. Developmental anomalies of the omentum may cause torsion. However, they are infrequent and almost exclusively found in children.  
❌ Herniation of abdominal contents  :
Incorrect: Abdominal hernias typically cause mild pain or pressure at the site of the hernia, and patients may feel or see a bulge at the outer abdomen. This patient’s imaging,  past medical history, and severe abdominal pain suggest omental torsion, not herniation.  
✅ Post-surgical adhesions:
Correct: See Main Explanation.   
❌ Bulk-forming tumor:
Incorrect: Tumors are an important cause of secondary omental torsion. However, given this patient’s past medical history of multiple abdominal surgeries and the absence  of an intra-abdominal tumor on CT, it is more likely that post-surgical adhesions lead to omental torsion.  
❌ Intestinal perforation:
Incorrect: Perforation of the GI tract can lead to pneumoperitoneum that can present with severe abdominal pain. However the CT does not show evidence of free air in the peritoneal cavity and the patient’s last surgery was one year ago.

questions.text:
A 56-year-old man presents to the emergency department to be evaluated for severe diffuse abdominal pain. He has associated nausea and vomiting. Past medical history is notable for four months of aching and burning epigastric pain, which worsens after eating. He has been managing the epigastric pain by taking over-the-counter antacids. At arrival, temperature is 37.9°C (100.2°F), pulse is 120/min, respirations are 22/min, and blood pressure is 120/66 mm Hg. Diffuse abdominal tenderness to palpation is noted on the physical examination. An upright abdominal radiograph is obtained and shown below. Which of the following best explains this patient’s underlying pathology?  


Image reproduced from Wikimedia Commons

choices.text: Interposed colon between the liver and diaphragm

questions.solution:
This patient presents with severe abdominal pain, nausea, and vomiting in the setting of chronic peptic ulcer disease. Imaging reveals free air under the diaphragm. The air in the lungs and gas under the diaphragm show the diaphragmatic contour in the chest radiograph above. In combination, these findings are concerning for pneumoperitoneum secondary to a perforated peptic ulcer.  

Pneumoperitoneum is a severe finding warranting urgent surgical management. The most common causes of pneumoperitoneum include peptic ulcer disease (45%), followed by appendicitis (18.5%), typhoid fever (12%), tuberculosis (10%), and trauma (9%). There are also non-surgical pathologies that are associated with pneumoperitoneum. However, these are exceedingly rare.    

An erect chest x-ray is the most sensitive imaging for diagnosing pneumoperitoneum. If large volume pneumoperitoneum is present, subdiaphragmatic free gas and a continuous diaphragm sign may be seen as in the image in this case. Other signs of pneumoperitoneum on radiographic imaging include:  

  1.  Cupola/saddlebag/mustache sign-seen on a supine radiograph, refers to air accumulation underneath the central tendon of the diaphragm in the midline. 
  2.  Rigler sign-air outlining both sides of the bowel wall. 
  3.  Lucent liver sign-reduction of liver opacity due to air located anterior to the liver. 
  4.  Football sign-seen in massive pneumoperitoneum, where the abdominal cavity is outlined by gas. 
  5.  Silver sign-also called a falciform ligament sign, wherein air outlines the falciform ligament. 
  6.  Inverted V sign-air outlining lateral umbilical ligaments (inferior epigastric vessels). 
  7.  Doge cap sign-triangular collection of gas in Morison pouch. 
  8.  Telltale triangle sign-triangular air pocket between three loops of bowel. 
  9.  Urachus sign-ar outlining the middle umbilical ligament. 

Option Analysis

❌ Interposed colon between the liver and diaphragm:
Incorrect: Chilaiditi sign is the radiographic observation of a distended gaseous colon segment interposed between the liver and diaphragm. Chilaiditi syndrome may present with a range of abdominal symptoms due to this interposed segment of colon. It can sometimes be mistaken for pneumoperitoneum. This patient’s abdominal radiograph shows a well-defined diaphragmatic contour indicating pneumoperitoneum.  
❌ Congestive heart failure:
Incorrect: The radiographic signs of congestive heart failure include cardiomegaly, prominent pulmonary vascular markings, and pleural effusions. These findings are absent in this patient’s imaging and he is not presenting with shortness of breath.  
❌ Ischemic bowel:
Incorrect: Ischemia of the small intestine can lead to small bowel perforation and pneumoperitoneum. However this patient’s history of epigastric pain after eating relieved with antacids is more suggestive of a perforated peptic ulcer.  
✅ Perforated peptic ulcer:
Correct: See Main Explanation.   
❌ Perforating tumor:
Incorrect: A perforating tumor can be a cause of small bowel perforation, however in addition to acute abdominal symptoms it would present with additional symptoms that would have been ongoing and indicative of underlying malignancy such as weight loss, rectal bleeding, and night sweats. This patient’s symptoms are more suggestive of pneumoperitoneum secondary to a perforated peptic ulcer.

questions.text:
A 26-year-old man is fighting in an international mixed martial arts contest. During the tournament, he sustains repeated abdominal blows from the opponent, followed by repeated blows to the left temple that render him unconscious. An on-site sports physician immediately assesses the patient. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 136/min, respirations are 25/min, and blood pressure is 130/66 mmHg. The patient’s oxygen saturation is 92%. As the patient awakens, he reflexively guards his left lower chest. An urgent chest radiograph is done on-site and is shown below. Which of the following explains why the diaphragmatic hernia seen below occurred on the left side, as opposed to the right?  


Image reproduced from Radiopedia

choices.text: Absence of floating ribs on the left
Fewer lung lobes on the left
Location of the spleen beneath left hemidiaphragm

questions.solution:
This patient sustained significant blunt force trauma to the abdomen and developed an acquired diaphragmatic hernia (ADH). ADH usually arises due to a sudden increase in pleuroperitoneal pressure resulting from blunt or penetrating trauma. Acquired diaphragmatic hernias occur at sites of weakness in the diaphragm that arise from embryonic fusion sites. They almost always occur in the left hemidiaphragm. This phenomenon occurs because the right hemidiaphragm is protected by the large size of the liver.    

Hiatal hernias also occur when gastrointestinal contents protrude into the chest cavity through an opening in the diaphragm. They protrude through the opening in the diaphragm called the hiatus. Hiatal hernias occur when the upper part of the stomach pushes up through the diaphragm into the chest cavity. There are two types of hiatal hernias: sliding hernias and paraesophageal hernias. Sliding hernias occur when the fundus of the stomach bulges directly into the thoracic cavity. In contrast, paraesophageal hernias occur when the gastric fundus bulges into the thoracic cavity adjacent to the esophagus. Sliding hernias are generally asymptomatic and more common than paraesophageal hernias. Paraesophageal hernias have the possibility of strangulation and, as a result, more often warrant surgical repair.  



Option Analysis

❌ Decreased bone mineral density:
Incorrect: This patient’s imaging reveals a left-sided diaphragmatic hernia without any evidence of fracture that could have been caused by low bone mineral density in conjunction with trauma. Moreover, this patient’s bones do not appear osteopenic on imaging.  
❌ Absence of floating ribs on the left:
Incorrect: The floating ribs are the lower ribs (11 and 12) that do not attach to the sternum. Floating ribs are normally present bilaterally and are seen in the image above. They do not play a role in developing diaphragmatic hernias.  
❌ Fewer lung lobes on the left:
Incorrect: The left lung has two lobes, whereas the right lung has three. However, the number of lobes does not account for why patients are more likely to develop left-sided diaphragmatic hernias.  
❌ Location of the spleen beneath left hemidiaphragm:
Incorrect: The spleen is located below the left hemidiaphragm. It does not play a protective role against diaphragmatic hernias on the left side. In contrast, the large size of the liver located below the right hemidiaphragm is thought to be protective against right diaphragmatic hernias.  
✅ Unprotected embryological points of weakness:
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text:
A 26-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by the local paramedics after a motor vehicle collision. He was wearing a seat belt while driving, and his car was hit by a truck from the left side. The patient reports severe abdominal pain radiating to the left shoulder, nausea, and dizziness. Temperature is 36.7°C (98°F), pulse is 110/min, respirations are 20/min and blood pressure is 85/50 mmHg. Physical examination shows an area of ecchymosis over the left lower chest wall, diffuse abdominal tenderness, and dullness to percussion over the left upper quadrant. Lungs are clear to auscultation bilaterally. Focused assessment with sonography for trauma (FAST) reveals intraperitoneal free fluid. CT scan with contrast of the abdomen and pelvis is performed, as shown below. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient’s presentation?  


Reproduced from: Radiopedia
questions.solution:
This patient suffered a blunt abdominal trauma (BAT) during a motor vehicle accident, has diffuse abdominal tenderness, left shoulder pain (Kehr’s sign), and signs of shock (hypotension, tachycardia). This together with free intraperitoneal fluid on Focused assessment with Sonography for Trauma (FAST), left lower chest ecchymosis, and left upper quadrant dullness to percussion is consistent with splenic laceration.   

The spleen lies within the intraperitoneal cavity in close proximity to the stomach (intraperitoneal), colon (transverse: intraperitoneal, descending: retroperitoneal), left kidney, and pancreas (both retroperitoneal). It is one of the most commonly injured intra-abdominal organs following blunt trauma. In most adults, the spleen does not extend inferiorly past the rib cage, unless it is otherwise enlarged. The spectrum of its injury can range from contusion or subcapsular hematoma to laceration and intraperitoneal bleeding (due to high vascularity).  

Patients can present with abdominal pain, tenderness in the epigastrium, pain in the left flank, and sharp left shoulder pain in cases of minor injury. Whereas, a ruptured spleen may result in massive intra-abdominal bleeding and should therefore be treated as a medical emergency.  

Option Analysis

❌ Duodenal hematoma:
Incorrect: Rapid compression of the abdomen against the vertebral column can crush the duodenum, potentially causing duodenal hematoma. It does not cause free intraperitoneal fluid as the bleeding remains confined to the duodenal wall. Moreover, this patient suffered trauma from the left side of his vehicle.  
❌ Abdominal aortic rupture:
Incorrect: Abdominal aortic rupture is frequently fatal due to the profuse bleeding that results from the rupture, and many patients die of examination before reaching the hospital. The minority of the patients who survive is most likely due to the containment of the blood in the retroperitoneal space. Moreover, a blunt trauma from the left side is less likely to cause aortic rupture.  
❌ Liver laceration:
Incorrect: Blunt force mechanisms such as motor vehicle accidents are a common cause of liver laceration, and FAST may show free intraperitoneal fluid. Tenderness, however, is located over the right upper quadrant (rather than LUQ as seen in this patient).  
❌ Diaphragmatic injury:
Incorrect: Diaphragmatic injury can occur after blunt trauma due to a sudden increase in intra abdominal pressure. Chest auscultation may reveal bowel sounds. Free intraperitoneal fluid on FAST in this patient is suggestive of splenic laceration.
✅ Splenic laceration:
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text: A 25-year-old man presents to the emergency department after being tackled during a football match. The patient was knocked to the ground by another player. He experienced sudden-onset sharp pain in the abdomen and left shoulder. He subsequently lost consciousness. Before the incident, the patient had been experiencing fatigue and sore throat for two weeks. He has no significant past medical history and was screened with an ECG prior to playing football. At arrival, temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), blood pressure is 90/60, and pulse is 110/min. Physical examination reveals diffuse abdominal guarding and rigidity. Elevation of the legs leads to the patient grimacing in pain and grabbing his left shoulder. Palpation of the left upper abdominal quadrant also causes the patient to grimace in pain. The bilateral tonsils are swollen and erythematous, and there is bilateral posterior cervical lymphadenopathy. Which of the following best explains this patient’s shoulder pain?

choices.text: Shoulder dislocation due to excessive force

questions.solution:
This patient presents with acute-onset abdominal pain and hypotension after being tackled during a football match. In addition, he likely has concurrent infectious mononucleosis given his symptoms of fatigue, sore throat, and findings of swollen, erythematous tonsils bilaterally with posterior cervical lymphadenopathy. In combination, these findings are concerning for a splenic rupture and associated internal bleeding.    

The patient experienced left shoulder pain after the tackle and grimaces from left shoulder pain when the legs are elevated. This finding of left shoulder pain from irritation of the left diaphragm is known as the Kehr Sign. It is a classic example of referred pain. The pathophysiology of Kehr Sign is the same as that of other types of referred pain: visceral pain in one location of the body is interpreted as somatic pain in another due to effects of temporal and spatial summation of nerves arising from the same spinal level.    
In this case, splenic rupture and filling of the abdominal cavity with blood irritates the inferior surface of the left diaphragm. Irritation of the underside of the diaphragm is signaled by the phrenic nerve which carries pain signals up to spinal nerve levels C3 and C4. The supraclavicular nerve, which innervates the skin over the shoulder, also inserts at cervical levels C3 and C4. As a result, there is referred pain to the left shoulder from splenic rupture.  

Option Analysis

❌ Shoulder dislocation due to excessive force:
Incorrect: Shoulder dislocation does not explain this patient’s abdominal symptoms, head and neck findings, and hypotension. Splenic rupture associated with trauma in a patient with mononucleosis infection is more likely the cause of this constellation of findings.  
❌ Undiagnosed tumor:
Incorrect: An undiagnosed intra-abdominal malignancy would  likely present with insidious and chronic pain. This patient has acute onset abdominal pain and hypotension after a traumatic tackle and signs of mononucleosis which would indicate splenic rupture.  
❌ Impingement of the supraclavicular nerve:
Incorrect: Impingement of this nerve would cause pain in the shoulder area. However, it would not account for the patient’s abdominal pain, hypotension, and head and neck findings.  
❌ Atypical myocardial infarction:
Incorrect: Although an atypical myocardial infarction can present with abdominal pain, it would not account for this patient’s symptoms of acute abdomen (e.g., diffuse guarding, rigidity), hypotension, and head and neck findings. Myocardial infarction would be unlikely in this young man with no prior medical history who had a screening ECG prior to playing sports.  
✅ Irritation of the diaphragm:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
